commentary_on_process:
To solve the problem, I created a table to organize the given information and focused on the yardage of the touchdown passes thrown by Carson Palmer. I added up the yardage of the two touchdown passes, which were 8 yards and 20 yards, to get a total of 28 yards. 

To solve the problem better, I could have also checked the passing statistics for the game to confirm the yardage of the touchdown passes thrown by Carson Palmer.
final_answer: Carson Palmer threw for 28 yards of touchdowns.
problem_text:
Context:
The Bengals week 14 game saw the 2-10 Raiders visiting Paul Brown Stadium. Chris Henry put the Bengals on the board first, on an 8-yard pass from Carson Palmer. Later in the first quarter, Rudi Johnson scored on a 9-yard run. In the second quarter, Sebastian Janikowski converted a 33-yard field goal attempt. The Bengals struck two more times in the third quarter on 6-yard Rudi Johnson run, and a 20-yard strike from Palmer to Houshmandzadeh. The lone Raider touchdown was scored on an Aaron Brooks-to-Ronald Curry 6-yard pass in the fourth quarter. The Bengal defensive kept the Raiders offense from threatening much of the game, allowing only 45 yards rushing. Even though quarterback Carson Palmer threw 3 interceptions (two to Nnamdi Asomugha and one to Fabian Washington), and running back Rudi Johnson turned the ball over in the second quarter, the 4 turnovers given to the Raiders were not enough opportunities for the Oakland offense to create points. Bengal mistakes were systemic, as even kicker Shayne Graham missed an extra point, bouncing the ball off the left upright in the third quarter. Cincinnati was not forced to punt once during this game. For the first time in Bengals' history, four players were over 100 yards in offensive production (Palmer, Houshmandzadeh, Chad Johnson and Rudi Johnson). The fourth straight win improved the Bengals' record to 8-5, and put them into wild card contention.

Question:
How many total yards of touchdowns did Carson Palmer have?

steps.step_response:
Yes, creating a list or table to organize the given information can be helpful. Here is an example:

| Scoring Play | Quarter | Yardage | Scorer | 
|--------------|---------|---------|--------|
| 8-yard pass from Carson Palmer | 1st | 8 yards | Chris Henry |
| 9-yard run | 1st | 9 yards | Rudi Johnson |
| 33-yard field goal | 2nd | 33 yards | Sebastian Janikowski |
| 6-yard run | 3rd | 6 yards | Rudi Johnson |
| 20-yard pass from Carson Palmer | 3rd | 20 yards | Houshmandzadeh |
| 6-yard pass from Aaron Brooks | 4th | 6 yards | Ronald Curry | 

Note: The table includes the scoring play, the quarter in which it occurred, the yardage of the play, and the player who scored.
